articles.headline: Facebook Fails to Appease Organizers of Ad Boycott
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s top executives, engaged in “spin” during a meeting over hate speech, civil rights groups said.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s top executives, engaged in “spin” during a meeting over hate speech, civil rights groups said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg and Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s two top executives, met with civil rights groups on Tuesday in an attempt to mollify them over how the social network treats hate speech on its site.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Trump Leans on Schools to Reopen as Virus Continues Its Spread
articles.snippet: President Trump spearheaded an administration-wide push to pry open the nation’s elementary and secondary schools, the next phase of his effort to get the economy on its feet.
articles.abstract: President Trump spearheaded an administration-wide push to pry open the nation’s elementary and secondary schools, the next phase of his effort to get the economy on its feet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Erica L. Green

articles.headline: Facebook’s Decisions Were ‘Setbacks for Civil Rights,’ Audit Finds
articles.snippet: An independent audit faulted the social network for allowing hate speech and disinformation to thrive — potentially posing a threat to the November elections.
articles.abstract: An independent audit faulted the social network for allowing hate speech and disinformation to thrive — potentially posing a threat to the November elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Auditors handpicked by Facebook to examine its policies said that the company had not done enough to protect people on the platform from discriminatory posts and ads and that its decisions to leave up President Trump’s inflammatory posts were “significant setbacks for civil rights.”

articles.headline: Erdogan Talks of Making Hagia Sophia a Mosque Again, to International Dismay
articles.snippet: The World Heritage site was once a potent symbol of Christian-Muslim rivalry, and it could become one once more.
articles.abstract: The World Heritage site was once a potent symbol of Christian-Muslim rivalry, and it could become one once more.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Since it was built in the sixth century, changing hands from empire to empire, Hagia Sophia has been a Byzantine cathedral, a mosque under the Ottomans and finally a museum, making it one of the world’s most potent symbols of Christian-Muslim rivalry and of Turkey’s more recent devotion to secularism.

articles.headline: Virus-Tracing Apps Are Rife With Problems. Governments Are Rushing to Fix Them.
articles.snippet: As countries race to deploy coronavirus-tracking software, researchers are reporting privacy and security risks that could affect millions of people and undermine trust in public health efforts.
articles.abstract: As countries race to deploy coronavirus-tracking software, researchers are reporting privacy and security risks that could affect millions of people and undermine trust in public health efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, Norway released a smartphone app, Smittestopp or “stop infection,” that records users who come into close contact for more than 15 minutes and sends alerts if they have been exposed to the coronavirus.

articles.headline: Disney World Draws Excitement and Incredulity as Reopening Nears
articles.snippet: The mega-resort will welcome back visitors on Saturday even as coronavirus cases in Florida remain high. In doing so, Disney steps into a politicized debate.
articles.abstract: The mega-resort will welcome back visitors on Saturday even as coronavirus cases in Florida remain high. In doing so, Disney steps into a politicized debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., will reopen on Saturday, and Disney has been posting marketing videos online to highlight the safety procedures it has designed to protect visitors and employees.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Upholds Trump Administration Regulation Letting Employers Opt Out of Birth Control Coverage
articles.snippet: The regulation was the latest attempt to undermine the “contraception mandate,” a signature initiative of the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The regulation was the latest attempt to undermine the “contraception mandate,” a signature initiative of the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld a Trump administration regulation that lets employers with religious or moral objections limit women’s access to birth control coverage under the Affordable Care Act and could result in as many as 126,000 women losing contraceptive coverage from their employers.

articles.headline: Brooks Brothers, Founded in 1818, Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The retailer, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, will close 51 U.S. stores as it looks for a buyer.
articles.abstract: The retailer, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, will close 51 U.S. stores as it looks for a buyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brooks Brothers, the retailer known for dressing the great and good of the United States since 1818, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday, buckling under the pressure from the coronavirus pandemic after years of faltering sales as customers embraced more casual apparel and sales shifted online.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Trump Threatens to Cut Funding if Schools Do Not Fully Reopen
articles.snippet: Disregarding the advice of his own health experts, President Trump also attacked the C.D.C.’s reopening guidelines as onerous and expensive.
articles.abstract: Disregarding the advice of his own health experts, President Trump also attacked the C.D.C.’s reopening guidelines as onerous and expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump pressured the government’s top public health experts on Wednesday to water down recommendations for how the nation’s schools could reopen safely this fall and threatened to cut federal funding for districts that defied his demand to resume classes in person.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Erica L. Green and Noah Weiland
